title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997". Congress finds that private security officers in the United States are growing rapidly and function as an adjunct to public law enforcement by helping to reduce and prevent crime. The private security industry offers opportunities for entry-level job applicants, including those facing unemployment. Private security officers protect individuals, property, and proprietary information in various operations such as banks. Private security officers protect diverse operations such as banks, hospitals, chemical companies, and airports. Sworn law enforcement officers provide significant services in public areas, supplemented by private security officers. Large private shopping malls have contributed to the growth of the private security industry. The growth of private shopping malls has led to a decrease in public shopping streets, resulting in more contact with private security personnel than sworn law enforcement officers. This trend has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, with the goal of making more officers available to combat serious crimes. Private security personnel play a crucial role in complementing sworn law enforcement officers, as the public struggles to differentiate between the two. It is essential to thoroughly screen private security officers, especially those who carry weapons. Background checks are crucial for private security personnel, especially those carrying weapons. The Attorney General requires private security officers to submit fingerprints for background checks, which can be authorized by the employer. The Interstate Information Index is searched for criminal records. The Attorney General mandates the submission of fingerprints by private security officers for background checks, utilizing the Interstate Information Index for criminal record searches. Identification and criminal history records are provided within 30 business days to requesting associations. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling criminal history information. Designated associations must promptly submit employee fingerprints for processing. The designated association must process identification and criminal history records within one business day and transfer them to the requesting employer promptly. Additionally, the association must provide copies of the information to licensing authorities and regulatory agencies in the relevant states. The Attorney General has the authority to establish regulations for this process. The Attorney General may prescribe regulations for the security, confidentiality, accuracy, and dissemination of information related to inquiries made by employers. A report on the number of inquiries must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary 2 years after the enactment of the bill. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Subsection (d) of section 534 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include an association of employers of private security officers designated by the Attorney General for conducting background checks on employees.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Anyone who misuses information obtained under section 3 for purposes other than assessing an individual's suitability for private security officer employment may face a fine of up to $50,000, imprisonment for up to two years, or both.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Where an employer relies on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions, they are not liable for damages. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Attorney General" includes any designated person or entity, such as the FBI. The term "employee" includes job applicants. The term "employer" refers to a person or entity that provides private security services as an independent contractor and is licensed or certified by one or more states. The term "private security officer" refers to an individual who performs security services, whether armed or unarmed, as an independent contractor or employee, approved by the Attorney General. Private security officers do not include sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal audit or credit employees, or individuals on active duty. Private security officers exclude sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal audit or credit employees, and individuals on active duty in the military service, employees of electronic security system companies, employees involved in the secure movement of prisoners, and employees of armored vehicle companies. Security services involve observing or reporting intrusion, larceny, vandalism, fire, or trespass. Private security officers are responsible for deterring theft, observing unlawful activities, protecting individuals and property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order at public events, and ensuring safety. Private security officers are responsible for deterring theft, observing unlawful activities, protecting individuals and property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order at public events, and ensuring safety. The term "State" refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, American Samoa, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The Attorney General may collect user fees for requests for criminal history information. The effective date of this Act is July 1, 1999.
